intro: Sisymbrium boryi, commonly known as the Bory's broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants. The plant produces small, yellow flowers and has a taproot system that allows it to attach to its host. It is typically found in dry, open habitats and is native to regions of Europe and western Asia. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have significant impacts on the growth and health of its host plants.
